metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Incorporates new SP 800-53 Rev 5 controls (AT-06, CA-09, CM-12, CM-13, IR-09, PL-09, PS-09, RA-07, RA-09, SC-24, SC-42, SC-45, SI-18). Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: The entity maintains, monitors, and evaluates current processing capacity and use of system components (infrastructure, data, and software) to manage capacity demand and to enable the implementation of additional capacity to help meet its objectives
clauses.rationale: AU-04, SC-05, CP-02, and CA-07 partially address capacity management in specific contexts.
clauses.gaps: Lacks comprehensive capacity management. SOC 2 A1.1 requires proactive capacity planning across all system components; SP 800-53 addresses capacity in narrow contexts (audit storage, DoS).

clauses.title: A1.1 POF1: Manages capacity to meet objectives — Processing capacity and use of system components are managed
clauses.rationale: AU-04 manages audit storage capacity; SC-05 protects against capacity exhaustion through DoS.
clauses.gaps: Gaps in comprehensive capacity planning, trending, threshold alerting, and proactive management across all infrastructure components.

clauses.title: The entity authorizes, designs, develops or acquires, implements, operates, approves, maintains, and monitors environmental protections, software, data backup processes, and recovery infrastructure to meet its objectives
clauses.rationale: PE family, CP-09, CP-06/CP-07/CP-08, and CP-10 provide comprehensive availability infrastructure. SC-24 (new in Rev 5) adds fail-safe recovery.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. SP 800-53 environmental and recovery controls are comprehensive.

clauses.title: A1.2 POF1: Implements recovery infrastructure and software — Recovery infrastructure is implemented and maintained
clauses.rationale: CP-06, CP-07, CP-09, and CP-10 provide recovery infrastructure.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Recovery infrastructure well-addressed.

clauses.title: A1.2 POF2: Implements environmental protections — Environmental protections for data centers and facilities are implemented
clauses.rationale: PE-09 through PE-15 provide comprehensive environmental protections for power, fire, temperature, and water damage.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. PE family is comprehensive for environmental protections.

clauses.title: A1.2 POF3: Implements data backup processes — Data backup and recovery processes are implemented and maintained
clauses.rationale: CP-09 directly addresses data backup processes including scheduling, testing, and offsite storage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. CP-09 comprehensively covers data backup.

clauses.title: The entity tests recovery plan procedures supporting system recovery to meet its objectives
clauses.rationale: CP-04, CP-03, and IR-03 directly address recovery plan testing.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. CP-04 directly requires recovery plan testing.

clauses.title: The entity identifies and maintains confidential information to meet the entity's objectives related to confidentiality
clauses.rationale: RA-02, AC-04, MP-03, and SC-28 address identification and protection. CM-12 (new in Rev 5) strengthens information location tracking.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap: SOC 2 C1.1 uses business-context confidentiality classification; SP 800-53 uses FIPS 199 methodology.

clauses.title: C1.1 POF1: Identifies confidential information — The entity has procedures to identify confidential information
clauses.rationale: RA-02 covers security categorization; MP-03 covers media labeling.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage through categorization. Minor gap in business-context confidentiality classification beyond security categorization.

clauses.title: The entity disposes of confidential information to meet the entity's objectives related to confidentiality
clauses.rationale: MP-06, SI-12, and SR-12 address secure disposal of confidential information.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. MP-06 provides comprehensive media sanitization; SI-12 covers retention and disposal policies.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 1: The entity demonstrates a commitment to integrity and ethical values
clauses.rationale: PS-08 addresses sanctions, PL-04 covers rules of behavior. PL-09 (new in Rev 5) adds central management of policy. However, SP 800-53 is a technical catalog and does not directly address ethical culture.
clauses.gaps: SOC 2 CC1.1 requires codes of conduct, board oversight of ethics, and deviation remediation. SP 800-53 lacks controls for ethical culture establishment and governance-level integrity.

clauses.title: CC1.1 POF1: Sets the tone at the top — The board of directors and management demonstrate commitment to integrity and ethical values
clauses.rationale: PM-01 and PM-02 establish security program leadership but do not address tone-at-the-top for integrity and ethics.
clauses.gaps: No SP 800-53 equivalent for board/management setting ethical tone. Focuses on security program management, not organizational ethics.

clauses.title: CC1.1 POF2: Establishes standards of conduct — Expectations of the board and senior management concerning integrity and ethical values are defined
clauses.rationale: PL-04 (Rules of Behavior) partially covers conduct standards but focuses on system use rather than broad ethics.
clauses.gaps: PL-04 covers system use rules but not enterprise-wide standards of conduct, codes of ethics, or integrity expectations.

clauses.title: CC1.1 POF3: Evaluates adherence to standards of conduct — Processes are in place to evaluate performance against standards of conduct
clauses.rationale: PS-08 addresses consequences for violations but does not cover systematic evaluation of adherence.
clauses.gaps: No SP 800-53 control for systematic evaluation of adherence to conduct standards. PS-08 is reactive, not proactive.

clauses.title: CC1.1 POF4: Addresses deviations in a timely manner — Deviations from standards of conduct are identified and remedied in a timely manner
clauses.rationale: PS-08 and IR-04 partially address deviation handling for security matters.
clauses.gaps: Addresses security-specific deviations but not general conduct deviations. No control for non-security behavioral deviation remediation.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 2: The board of directors demonstrates independence from management and exercises oversight of the development and performance of internal control
clauses.rationale: PM-01/PM-02 establish governance roles; CA-02/CA-07 provide assessment. Board independence and oversight of internal control are outside SP 800-53 scope.
clauses.gaps: SOC 2 CC1.2 requires board independence, competence, and oversight. SP 800-53 does not address board governance or board-level oversight.

clauses.title: CC1.2 POF1: Establishes oversight responsibilities — The board identifies and accepts its oversight responsibilities in relation to established requirements and expectations
clauses.rationale: PM-02 assigns security roles but does not address board-level oversight responsibilities.
clauses.gaps: Focuses on operational security roles, not board governance responsibilities or fiduciary duties.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 3: Management establishes, with board oversight, structures, reporting lines, and appropriate authorities and responsibilities in the pursuit of objectives
clauses.rationale: PM-01, PM-02, and PM-10 establish organizational structures and responsibilities for security. Partially addresses within security scope.
clauses.gaps: Covers security-specific organizational structure but not enterprise-wide organizational design, authority delegation, or non-security reporting lines.

clauses.title: CC1.3 POF1: Considers all structures of the entity — Management and the board consider the multiple structures used to support the achievement of objectives
clauses.rationale: PM-07 and PM-01 consider security program structure but not all organizational structures.
clauses.gaps: Addresses security program structure only. SOC 2 requires consideration of all structures including business units, legal entities, and locations.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 4: The entity demonstrates a commitment to attract, develop, and retain competent individuals in alignment with objectives
clauses.rationale: PM-13, AT-01/AT-02/AT-03, and PS-02 address workforce competence. AT-06 (new in Rev 5) adds training feedback. PS-09 (new in Rev 5) adds position descriptions.
clauses.gaps: Extends to all personnel, not just security staff. Gaps in general HR competency management, career development, and succession planning.

clauses.title: CC1.4 POF1: Establishes policies and practices — Policies and practices reflect expectations of competence necessary to support the achievement of objectives
clauses.rationale: AT-01 establishes training policy; PM-13 addresses security workforce competence requirements.
clauses.gaps: Covers security competence policies. Gaps in broader organizational competence requirements and enterprise-wide competency frameworks.

clauses.title: CC1.4 POF2: Evaluates competence and addresses shortcomings — The board and management evaluate competence and address shortcomings
clauses.rationale: PM-13 includes workforce planning; AT-04 tracks training records. AT-06 (new in Rev 5) adds training feedback enabling competence evaluation.
clauses.gaps: Supports competence tracking for security roles. Does not cover board-level or executive competence assessment or enterprise-wide gap remediation.

clauses.title: CC1.4 POF3: Attracts, develops, and retains individuals — The entity provides mentoring and training to attract, develop, and retain sufficient and competent personnel
clauses.rationale: AT-02, AT-03 provide training; PM-13 addresses workforce development.
clauses.gaps: Good security training coverage. Gaps in general talent acquisition, mentoring programs, retention strategies, and non-security development.

clauses.title: CC1.4 POF4: Plans and prepares for succession — Senior management and the board develop succession plans for key roles
clauses.rationale: No direct SP 800-53 control for succession planning.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. PM-02 identifies key security roles but no succession or continuity of leadership requirements.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 5: The entity holds individuals accountable for their internal control responsibilities in the pursuit of objectives
clauses.rationale: PS-01, PS-08, PM-02, and PL-04 establish accountability. PS-09 (new in Rev 5) adds position descriptions strengthening role accountability.
clauses.gaps: Covers security accountability through sanctions and role assignment. Lacks broader accountability structures, performance metrics, and incentive alignment.

clauses.title: CC1.5 POF1: Enforces accountability through structures, authorities, and responsibilities — Management and the board establish mechanisms to communicate and hold individuals accountable
clauses.rationale: PM-02 assigns authority; PS-08 enforces through sanctions; PL-04 communicates expectations.
clauses.gaps: Covers security-specific accountability. Gaps in enterprise-wide accountability structures and board-level accountability mechanisms.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 13: The entity obtains or generates and uses relevant, quality information to support the functioning of internal control
clauses.rationale: AU-02/AU-03/AU-06, SI-04, and RA-03 generate and use security-relevant information. CA-07 uses control information systematically.
clauses.gaps: Good security information coverage. SOC 2 CC2.1 extends to all information supporting internal control including financial and operational.

clauses.title: CC2.1 POF1: Identifies information requirements — A process is in place to identify information required to support internal control
clauses.rationale: AU-02 identifies auditable events; RA-03 identifies risk information needs.
clauses.gaps: Covers security information requirements. Gaps in identifying information requirements for non-security internal controls and financial reporting.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 14: The entity internally communicates information, including objectives and responsibilities for internal control, necessary to support the functioning of internal control
clauses.rationale: AT-02, PM-01, PL-04, and IR-07 support internal communication of security-related information and responsibilities.
clauses.gaps: Covers security communication well. Does not address enterprise-wide internal control communication or management reporting on control effectiveness.

clauses.title: CC2.2 POF1: Communicates internal control information — A process is in place to communicate required information to enable all personnel to understand and carry out their responsibilities
clauses.rationale: AT-02 communicates security awareness; PL-04 communicates rules of behavior; PM-01 disseminates program plan.
clauses.gaps: Security communication well addressed. Gaps in communicating non-security internal control responsibilities and operational control expectations.

clauses.title: CC2.2 POF3: Communicates with the board of directors — Information necessary for the board to oversee internal control is communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-06 and CA-02 produce reports that could inform board communication.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 does not require board-level reporting. No control specifies board communication cadence, format, or content requirements.

clauses.title: CC2.2 POF7: Communicates objectives and changes to objectives — The entity communicates its objectives and changes to those objectives
clauses.rationale: PM-01 includes security program objectives; CM-03 communicates configuration changes.
clauses.gaps: Security objectives communicated via PM-01. Gaps in communicating enterprise-wide control objectives beyond security.

clauses.title: CC2.2 POF10: Provides separate communication lines — Separate communication channels such as whistle-blower hotlines are in place and serve as fail-safe mechanisms
clauses.rationale: No SP 800-53 control addresses separate communication lines or whistle-blower mechanisms.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. Does not address anonymous reporting channels, whistle-blower hotlines, or alternative communication paths for control concerns.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 15: The entity communicates with external parties regarding matters affecting the functioning of internal control
clauses.rationale: IR-06 covers external incident communication; PM-15 addresses external security community; SA-09 addresses service provider communication.
clauses.gaps: Covers security-specific external communication but not broader stakeholder communication about control effectiveness.

clauses.title: CC2.3 POF1: Communicates to external parties — Processes are in place to communicate relevant information to external parties
clauses.rationale: IR-06 covers incident reporting to authorities; PM-15 covers security community engagement; CA-03 manages information exchange agreements.
clauses.gaps: Security-specific external communication covered. Gaps in customer communication about controls and regulatory reporting beyond incidents.

clauses.title: CC2.3 POF12: Provides information on notification agreements — The entity notifies external parties of system changes affecting their operation
clauses.rationale: SR-08 directly addresses notification requirements in supply chain. CA-03 covers information exchange agreements.
clauses.gaps: SR-08 covers supply chain notification. Gaps in broader customer notification about system changes and proactive stakeholder notification.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 6: The entity specifies objectives with sufficient clarity to enable the identification and assessment of risks relating to objectives
clauses.rationale: PM-01 and PM-09 define security objectives. RA-03 requires clear risk context. RA-09 (new in Rev 5) adds criticality analysis strengthening objective specification.
clauses.gaps: Covers security objective specification but not enterprise-wide objective setting for risk assessment purposes.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 7: The entity identifies risks to the achievement of its objectives across the entity and analyzes risks as a basis for determining how the risks should be managed
clauses.rationale: RA family comprehensively covers risk identification and analysis. RA-07 (new in Rev 5) adds risk response providing structured risk treatment decisions.
clauses.gaps: Strong security risk coverage. Minor gaps: CC3.2 includes operational and compliance risks beyond information security.

clauses.title: CC3.2 POF1: Includes entity, subsidiary, division, operating unit, and functional levels
clauses.rationale: RA-03 covers risk assessment at system and organizational levels. PM-09 addresses organization-wide risk strategy.
clauses.gaps: Addresses risk at system and organizational levels. Gaps in structured assessment across subsidiary/division/functional levels as distinct entities.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 8: The entity considers the potential for fraud in assessing risks to the achievement of objectives
clauses.rationale: AC-05 and AU-06 support fraud detection. SI-04 can detect anomalous behavior.
clauses.gaps: Does not explicitly require fraud risk assessment. SOC 2 CC3.3 requires consideration of fraud incentives, opportunities, and rationalizations.

clauses.title: CC3.3 POF1: Considers various types of fraud — The entity considers fraudulent reporting, possible loss of assets, and corruption
clauses.rationale: AU-06 and SI-04 provide monitoring that could detect fraud indicators.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. No controls for fraud triangle analysis or assessing fraudulent reporting risk.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 9: The entity identifies and assesses changes that could significantly impact the system of internal control
clauses.rationale: CM-03/CM-04, RA-03, and CA-07 address change assessment for security-impacting changes.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage for security changes. SOC 2 CC3.4 extends to regulatory, technology, business model, and personnel changes.

clauses.title: CC3.4 POF1: Assesses changes in the external environment — The entity considers changes in regulatory, economic, and physical environments
clauses.rationale: SI-05 and PM-16 address external security environment changes.
clauses.gaps: Covers external security threat landscape. Gaps in regulatory environment changes, economic conditions, and broader external factor impacts.

clauses.title: CC3.4 POF2: Assesses changes in the business model — The entity considers the impact of new business lines, altered compositions of existing business lines, and acquired or divested business operations
clauses.rationale: PM-07 touches on business alignment but not business model change assessment.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. Does not address business model change impact, M&A integration risks, or new business line control requirements.

clauses.title: CC3.4 POF3: Assesses changes in leadership — The entity considers changes in management and other personnel
clauses.rationale: PS-04 and PS-05 address personnel changes from a security perspective.
clauses.gaps: Covers access changes due to personnel transitions. Does not address leadership change impact on internal control effectiveness.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 16: The entity selects, develops, and performs ongoing and/or separate evaluations to ascertain whether the components of internal control are present and functioning
clauses.rationale: CA-02, CA-07, PM-06, and AU-06 provide strong evaluation capabilities for security controls.
clauses.gaps: Good security control evaluation. SOC 2 CC4.1 extends to all internal control components including non-security controls.

clauses.title: CC4.1 POF1: Considers a mix of ongoing and separate evaluations — Management includes a balance of ongoing evaluations built into processes and separate evaluations
clauses.rationale: CA-07 provides ongoing monitoring; CA-02 provides separate assessments. Good balance for security controls.
clauses.gaps: Well-addressed for security. Gaps in ongoing/separate evaluation methodology for non-security internal controls.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 17: The entity evaluates and communicates internal control deficiencies in a timely manner to those parties responsible for taking corrective action, including senior management and the board of directors, as appropriate
clauses.rationale: CA-05 (POA&M) tracks deficiencies; CA-02 reports results; PM-06 reports metrics. IR-06 covers incident reporting.
clauses.gaps: Good deficiency tracking. SOC 2 CC4.2 requires board-level communication; SP 800-53 POA&M does not explicitly require board reporting.

clauses.title: CC4.2 POF1: Assesses results — Management and the board assess results of ongoing and separate evaluations
clauses.rationale: CA-02 results feed into authorization decisions; PM-06 provides measures; CA-05 tracks remediation.
clauses.gaps: Security assessment results well-managed. Gaps in board-level assessment and non-security control evaluation reviews.

clauses.title: CC4.2 POF2: Communicates deficiencies — Deficiencies are communicated to parties responsible for taking corrective action and to senior management and the board as appropriate
clauses.rationale: CA-05 communicates through POA&M; IR-06 reports incidents; PM-06 provides metrics.
clauses.gaps: Security deficiency communication well-established. Gaps in board-level deficiency communication and formal escalation paths.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 10: The entity selects and develops control activities that contribute to the mitigation of risks to the achievement of objectives to acceptable levels
clauses.rationale: The SP 800-53 catalog provides control activities mitigating security risks. PM-09 guides selection; CA-02 validates effectiveness.
clauses.gaps: Strong security control selection. SOC 2 CC5.1 extends to operational and compliance control activities beyond security.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 11: The entity also selects and develops general control activities over technology to support the achievement of objectives
clauses.rationale: SP 800-53 comprehensively covers technology general controls across access control, change management, system protection, and monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Minor gap: SOC 2 frames these as supporting all objectives; SP 800-53 frames them as security controls.

clauses.title: CC5.2 POF1: Determines dependency between the use of technology in business processes and technology general controls
clauses.rationale: PM-07 and SA-03 address technology-business alignment.
clauses.gaps: Addresses technology controls but explicit dependency mapping between business processes and IT general controls is not directly required.

clauses.title: COSO Principle 12: The entity deploys control activities through policies that establish what is expected and in procedures that put policies into action
clauses.rationale: Every family starts with policy/procedure. PL-09 (new in Rev 5) adds central management strengthening policy deployment.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. Every family has a -01 policy control. Minor gap: SOC 2 expects policies for all control activities, not just security.

clauses.title: CC5.3 POF1: Establishes policies and procedures to support deployment of management's directives
clauses.rationale: Every SP 800-53 family includes a -01 control requiring policy and procedures. Consistent pattern.
clauses.gaps: Excellent for security policies and procedures. Minor gap in non-security management directive deployment.

clauses.title: CC5.3 POF6: Reassesses policies and procedures — Management periodically reassesses policies and procedures for continued relevance and effectiveness
clauses.rationale: All -01 controls require periodic review and update. PM-01 requires program plan updates.
clauses.gaps: Requires periodic review of all security policies. Minor gap in linking reassessment to changing business conditions.

clauses.title: Logical and Physical Access Controls — The entity implements logical access security software, infrastructure, and architectures over protected information assets to protect them from security events to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: AC, IA, PE families and SC-07 provide comprehensive access controls. CA-09 (new in Rev 5) adds internal system connections strengthening internal access governance.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Minor gap: SOC 2 frames in entity objective terms; SP 800-53 is more technically prescriptive.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF1: Identifies and manages the inventory of information assets — The entity identifies and manages information assets
clauses.rationale: CM-08 and PM-05 cover asset identification. CM-12 (new in Rev 5) adds information location tracking strengthening asset-to-data mapping.
clauses.gaps: Good asset inventory. Minor gap in non-IT information asset inventory (paper records, intellectual property catalogs).

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF2: Restricts logical access — Access to information assets is restricted through logical access security measures
clauses.rationale: AC-03, AC-06, AC-02, and AC-17 comprehensively cover logical access restriction.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF3: Considers network segmentation — Network segmentation is implemented to restrict access
clauses.rationale: SC-07 directly addresses network segmentation. AC-04 controls data flow between segments.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SC-07 is comprehensive for network segmentation.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF4: Manages points of access — Points of access to information assets are managed and protected
clauses.rationale: SC-07 manages network access points; AC-17 manages remote entry points; PE-03 manages physical access points.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. Minor gap in comprehensive access point inventory as a unified concept.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF5: Restricts access to information assets — Access to information assets is restricted through identity management
clauses.rationale: IA-02, IA-04, IA-05, and AC-02 provide comprehensive identity-based access restriction.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF6: Manages identification and authentication — User identification and authentication is managed
clauses.rationale: IA family comprehensively covers identification and authentication including MFA, authenticator lifecycle, and identity proofing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF7: Manages credentials for infrastructure and software — System and application credentials are managed
clauses.rationale: IA-05 covers credential management; CM-06 includes credential configuration; SA-04 requires security capabilities in acquisitions.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. Minor gap in application-level credential management and service account lifecycle.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF8: Uses encryption to protect data — Encryption is used to protect data at rest and in transit
clauses.rationale: SC-12, SC-13, SC-08, and SC-28 provide comprehensive encryption coverage for data at rest and in transit.
clauses.gaps: Excellent encryption coverage. Minor gap: SOC 2 frames in access control context; SP 800-53 treats as system/communications protection.

clauses.title: CC6.1 POF9: Protects encryption keys — Encryption keys are managed to protect data
clauses.rationale: SC-12 directly addresses key management including generation, distribution, storage, and destruction.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. SC-12 comprehensively addresses key management lifecycle.

clauses.title: Prior to issuing system credentials and granting system access, the entity registers and authorizes new internal and external users whose access is administered by the entity
clauses.rationale: AC-02 covers user registration, authorization, and provisioning. PS-03 covers pre-access screening. IA-04 covers credential issuance.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Minor gap in external user lifecycle management specifics.

clauses.title: CC6.2 POF1: Controls access credentials to protected assets — New internal and external users are registered and authorized prior to being issued credentials and granted access
clauses.rationale: AC-02 requires authorization before account creation; PS-03 requires screening; IA-04 manages identifiers.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Pre-access authorization well covered.

clauses.title: The entity authorizes, modifies, or removes access to data, software, functions, and other protected information assets based on roles, responsibilities, or the system design and changes, giving consideration to the concepts of least privilege and segregation of duties
clauses.rationale: AC-02, AC-03, AC-05, AC-06, PS-04, and PS-05 directly address access lifecycle with least privilege and SoD.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Comprehensively covers access authorization, modification, and removal.

clauses.title: CC6.3 POF1: Creates or modifies access — Processes are in place to create or modify access to protected assets
clauses.rationale: AC-02 covers account creation, modification, and lifecycle management. AC-06 enforces least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The entity restricts physical access to facilities and protected information assets to authorized personnel to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: PE-02, PE-03, PE-06, and PE-08 provide comprehensive physical access control.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. PE family directly addresses physical access restriction.

clauses.title: The entity discontinues logical and physical access to protected information assets when that access is no longer required
clauses.rationale: PS-04, PS-05, AC-02, and PE-02 address access discontinuation across logical and physical access.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Access revocation on termination and transfer well-addressed.

clauses.title: The entity implements logical access security measures to protect against threats from sources outside its system boundaries
clauses.rationale: SC-07, AC-04, SI-03, SI-04, SC-08, and AC-17 provide defense against external threats.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Boundary protection and external threat mitigation are comprehensive.

clauses.title: CC6.6 POF1: Restricts access — The entity restricts access through network security and entry points
clauses.rationale: SC-07 provides boundary protection; AC-17 manages remote access; SC-08 protects transmissions.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Network access restriction from external sources well-covered.

clauses.title: CC6.6 POF2: Protects identification and authentication credentials — Identification and authentication credentials are protected during transmission outside system boundaries
clauses.rationale: SC-08, SC-13, and IA-05 protect credentials in transit.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage for credential protection during external transmission.

clauses.title: CC6.6 POF3: Requires additional authentication or credentials — Additional authentication measures are required for access from outside system boundaries
clauses.rationale: AC-17 and IA-02 (MFA for remote) address additional authentication for external access.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in adaptive authentication requirements.

clauses.title: The entity restricts the transmission, movement, and removal of information to authorized internal and external users and processes, and protects it during transmission, movement, or removal to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: AC-04, MP-05, SC-07, SC-08, SC-28, and PE-16 cover information movement. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) adds data action mapping for tracking data flows.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. Minor gap in comprehensive data loss prevention as an integrated concept.

clauses.title: CC6.7 POF1: Restricts the ability to perform transmission — Data loss prevention processes are in place to detect and prevent unauthorized transmission
clauses.rationale: AC-04, SC-07, SI-04, and PE-19 partially address DLP.
clauses.gaps: Provides building blocks for DLP but no single integrated DLP control. Gaps in comprehensive DLP covering all transmission vectors.

clauses.title: The entity implements controls to prevent or detect and act upon the introduction of unauthorized or malicious software to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: SI-03, SI-07, CM-07, CM-11, and SI-04 comprehensively address malware prevention and detection.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. SI-03 directly addresses malicious code protection.

clauses.title: To meet its objectives, the entity uses detection and monitoring procedures to identify changes to configurations that result in the introduction of new vulnerabilities, and susceptibilities to newly discovered vulnerabilities
clauses.rationale: CM-03/CM-04, RA-05, SI-04, SI-05, and CA-07 provide comprehensive detection. CA-09 (new in Rev 5) monitors internal connections. SC-45 (new in Rev 5) adds time synchronization for monitoring accuracy.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Vulnerability and configuration monitoring is comprehensive.

clauses.title: CC7.1 POF1: Uses defined configuration standards — The entity uses defined configuration standards to assess newly deployed or changed IT assets
clauses.rationale: CM-02, CM-06, and CM-03 directly address configuration standards.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Configuration baseline and standard management well-covered.

clauses.title: The entity monitors system components and the operation of those components for anomalies that are indicative of malicious acts, natural disasters, and errors affecting the entity's ability to meet its objectives; anomalies are analyzed to determine whether they represent security events
clauses.rationale: SI-04, AU-06, IR-04, IR-05, and CA-07 provide comprehensive anomaly detection. SC-45 (new in Rev 5) ensures accurate timestamps for correlation.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. Monitoring, detection, and analysis capabilities are comprehensive.

clauses.title: CC7.2 POF1: Implements detection policies, procedures, and tools — The entity implements and maintains detection policies, procedures, and tools
clauses.rationale: SI-04, AU-02, AU-06, and IR-01 cover detection policies, procedures, and tools.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Detection capability well-addressed.

clauses.title: CC7.2 POF2: Designs detection measures — Detection measures are designed to identify anomalies including known and unknown threats
clauses.rationale: SI-04 monitors for anomalies; PM-16 covers threat intelligence; RA-05 identifies vulnerabilities.
clauses.gaps: Good known threat coverage. Minor gap in explicit requirements for unknown/zero-day threat detection and behavioral analytics.

clauses.title: The entity evaluates security events to determine whether they could or have resulted in a failure of the entity to meet its objectives (security incidents) and, if so, takes actions to prevent or address such failures
clauses.rationale: IR-04, IR-05, IR-06, and AU-06 provide comprehensive event evaluation and incident determination.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. IR family directly addresses event evaluation and corrective action.

clauses.title: CC7.3 POF1: Responds to security incidents — Procedures are in place to respond to security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-01, IR-04, and IR-08 directly cover incident response procedures.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The entity responds to identified security incidents by executing a defined incident response program to understand, contain, remediate, and communicate security incidents, as appropriate
clauses.rationale: IR family provides a complete incident response program. IR-09 (new in Rev 5) adds information spillage response for data breach scenarios.
clauses.gaps: Excellent coverage. SP 800-53 IR family is comprehensive for incident response.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF1: Assigns roles and responsibilities — Roles and responsibilities for responding to incidents are assigned
clauses.rationale: IR-01 and IR-08 define incident response roles; PM-02 assigns security roles.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF2: Contains security incidents — Processes are in place to contain security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-04 directly addresses containment activities.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF3: Mitigates ongoing security incidents — Procedures are in place to mitigate the effects of ongoing incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-04 covers mitigation; SI-02 supports remediation activities.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in explicit ongoing mitigation versus containment distinction.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF4: Ends threats posed by security incidents — Steps are taken to end the threats posed by security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-04 includes eradication; CP-10 addresses reconstitution.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in explicit threat elimination verification requirements.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF5: Restores operations — Procedures are in place to restore normal operations
clauses.rationale: CP-10, CP-02, and IR-04 include recovery. SC-24 (new in Rev 5) adds fail-in-known-state capability ensuring systems restore to secure configurations.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. CP family addresses recovery. Minor gap in linking recovery to business objectives explicitly.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF6: Develops and implements communication protocols for security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-06, IR-07, and IR-08 include communication elements.
clauses.gaps: Good internal communication. Minor gap in structured external communication protocols for customer/stakeholder incidents.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF10: Meets regulatory notification requirements — The entity meets notification requirements for security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-06 addresses reporting to authorities.
clauses.gaps: Covers reporting to designated authorities. Gaps in multi-jurisdiction notification requirements and notification timeline management.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF11: Obtains understanding of nature of incident — The entity obtains understanding of the incident nature and scope
clauses.rationale: IR-04 includes analysis and scoping; AU-06 supports forensic analysis.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Incident analysis and scoping well-addressed.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF12: Remediates identified vulnerabilities — The entity remediates identified vulnerabilities following incidents
clauses.rationale: SI-02, CA-05, and IR-03 address post-incident vulnerability remediation.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in formal post-incident remediation verification.

clauses.title: CC7.4 POF13: Evaluates the effectiveness of incident response — The entity evaluates incident response effectiveness
clauses.rationale: IR-03 includes lessons learned and effectiveness evaluation. CA-02 provides broader assessment.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in formal metrics-based incident response program improvement.

clauses.title: The entity identifies, develops, and implements activities to recover from identified security incidents
clauses.rationale: CP-02, CP-10, IR-04, and IR-03 address incident recovery.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in explicit post-incident business recovery planning.

clauses.title: The entity authorizes, designs, develops or acquires, configures, documents, tests, approves, and implements changes to infrastructure, data, software, and procedures required to meet its objectives
clauses.rationale: CM-03, CM-04, CM-05, SA-10, SA-11, and SA-04 comprehensively cover change management.
clauses.gaps: Strong coverage. Minor gap: SOC 2 includes procedure and data changes explicitly; SP 800-53 focuses primarily on IT configuration changes.

clauses.title: CC8.1 POF1: Manages changes throughout the system life cycle — Processes are in place to manage changes to system components through the life cycle
clauses.rationale: SA-03, CM-03, and SA-10 cover lifecycle change management.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Minor gap in managing changes to business processes and procedures beyond IT systems.

clauses.title: The entity identifies, selects, and develops risk mitigation activities for risks arising from potential business disruptions
clauses.rationale: CP-01/CP-02/CP-04, RA-03, and PM-09 address disruption risk. RA-07 (new in Rev 5) adds structured risk response. RA-09 (new in Rev 5) adds criticality analysis for prioritization.
clauses.gaps: Good IT disruption coverage. SOC 2 CC9.1 extends to non-IT, supply chain, and market disruptions.

clauses.title: CC9.1 POF1: Considers mitigation through business continuity — The entity considers mitigation through contingency planning
clauses.rationale: CP family provides comprehensive contingency planning and business continuity for IT systems.
clauses.gaps: Strong IT continuity coverage. Minor gap in non-IT business continuity and crisis management.

clauses.title: The entity assesses and manages risks associated with vendors and business partners
clauses.rationale: SA-04, SA-09, SR-01/SR-02/SR-03, SR-05, and SR-06 provide vendor risk management.
clauses.gaps: Good technology vendor coverage. Gaps in non-technology vendor and business partner risk assessment.

clauses.title: CC9.2 POF1: Creates policies for vendor and business partner risk management — Vendor risk management processes are established
clauses.rationale: SR-01 and SA-04 establish vendor management policies.
clauses.gaps: Good IT vendor policies. Minor gap in non-technology vendor and business partner risk policies.

clauses.title: CC9.2 POF13: Assesses vendor and business partner risks — The entity periodically assesses vendor and business partner risks
clauses.rationale: SR-06 directly addresses periodic vendor assessment.
clauses.gaps: Good coverage. Gaps in non-supplier business partner risk assessment and comprehensive vendor risk scoring.

clauses.title: Privacy Criteria Introduction — The entity's privacy practices meet its objectives
clauses.rationale: PT family added in Rev 5 provides privacy controls. PM-25/PM-26/PM-27 address privacy program management. SC-42 (new in Rev 5) adds sensor capability controls for privacy-invasive data collection.
clauses.gaps: Rev 5 improved privacy coverage with PT family. SOC 2 privacy criteria are based on GAPP which is broader than federal privacy in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: The entity provides notice to data subjects about its privacy practices to meet the entity's objectives related to privacy
clauses.rationale: PT-05 directly addresses privacy notice. PT-03 requires purpose specification.
clauses.gaps: PT-05 covers notice. Gaps in notice timing, content specifics, and accessibility across all channels.

clauses.title: P1.1 POF1: Communicates to data subjects — Privacy notices are provided to data subjects
clauses.rationale: PT-05 addresses notice provision.
clauses.gaps: Covers notice delivery. Gaps in specific content requirements, multi-language support, and channel-specific formats.

clauses.title: P1.1 POF5: Provides notice of changes — Data subjects are notified of changes to the entity's privacy practices
clauses.rationale: PT-05 may require notice updates. No specific control for change notification to data subjects.
clauses.gaps: Does not explicitly require notification to data subjects when privacy practices change. Gap in change notification timing and opt-out.

clauses.title: The entity communicates choices available regarding the collection, use, retention, disclosure, and disposal of personal information to data subjects and obtains consent
clauses.rationale: PT-04 addresses consent. PT-02 covers legal basis for processing.
clauses.gaps: Gaps in comprehensive choice mechanisms (opt-in/out, granular consent), presentation at collection, and ongoing consent management.

clauses.title: The entity collects personal information only for the purposes identified in the notice to the data subject
clauses.rationale: PT-03 requires purpose specification. PT-02 limits processing to authorized purposes. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) maps data actions. SC-42 (new in Rev 5) controls sensor data collection.
clauses.gaps: Addresses purpose limitation. Gaps in purpose enforcement at collection point and preventing scope creep.

clauses.title: The entity limits the use of personal information to the purposes identified in the notice and for which the data subject has provided explicit consent
clauses.rationale: PT-03 and PT-02 address use limitation. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) data action mapping helps document and enforce use boundaries.
clauses.gaps: Covers purpose limitation conceptually. Gaps in enforcement mechanisms, secondary use prevention, and audit of actual use against stated purposes.

clauses.title: The entity retains personal information consistent with the entity's objectives related to privacy
clauses.rationale: SI-12 and PT-03 address retention. MP-06 supports disposal. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) helps document retention context through data action mapping.
clauses.gaps: Covers retention and disposal. Gaps in retention schedule alignment with privacy notice and automated enforcement based on purpose completion.

clauses.title: The entity disposes of personal information to meet the entity's privacy objectives
clauses.rationale: MP-06, SI-12, and SR-12 address secure disposal. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) supports disposal tracking through data action mapping.
clauses.gaps: Good technical disposal coverage. Minor gaps in privacy-specific disposal triggers and third-party disposal enforcement.

clauses.title: The entity discloses personal information to third parties with the consent of the data subject or as authorized under applicable law or regulation
clauses.rationale: PT-04 and SA-09 partially address third-party disclosure. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) data action mapping helps track disclosure flows.
clauses.gaps: Gaps in third-party disclosure tracking, consent verification before sharing, use limitation agreements, and cross-border transfer requirements.

clauses.title: The entity provides data subjects with access to their personal information for review and correction
clauses.rationale: PT-06 addresses individual access in the federal context. SI-18 (new in Rev 5) adds PII quality operations supporting data accuracy mechanisms.
clauses.gaps: PT-06 is Privacy Act-specific. Gaps in general data subject access rights, access request processing, and identity verification for requests.

clauses.title: The entity provides data subjects the ability to update and correct personal information
clauses.rationale: PT-06 addresses correction in federal context. SI-18 (new in Rev 5) PII quality operations supports data correction and accuracy maintenance.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap for commercial context. No general control for correction mechanisms, verification, or propagation of corrections to third parties.

clauses.title: The entity obtains or generates, uses, and communicates relevant, quality information regarding the objectives related to processing, including definitions of data processed and product and service specifications, to support the use of products and services
clauses.rationale: SA-05, SI-10, and SI-12 partially address processing information quality.
clauses.gaps: SOC 2 PI1.1 focuses on processing integrity including data definitions and specifications. SP 800-53 addresses validation and documentation but not business-level processing specs.

clauses.title: The entity implements policies and procedures over system inputs, including controls over completeness and accuracy, to result in products, services, and reporting to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: SI-09, SI-10, and AU-10 address input controls.
clauses.gaps: Provides input validation and accuracy controls. Gaps in comprehensive input completeness verification and end-to-end processing integrity.

clauses.title: The entity implements policies and procedures over system processing to result in products, services, and reporting to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: SI-07, SI-10, and AU-02/AU-03 address processing controls.
clauses.gaps: Provides integrity verification and audit. Gaps in business process validation, transaction processing integrity, and output reconciliation.

clauses.title: The entity implements policies and procedures to make available or deliver output completely, accurately, and timely in accordance with specifications to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: SI-12, AU-03, and PE-05 partially address output controls.
clauses.gaps: Addresses output handling and audit trails. Gaps in output completeness verification, accuracy validation, and delivery confirmation.

clauses.title: The entity implements policies and procedures to store inputs, items in processing, and outputs completely, accurately, and timely in accordance with system specifications to meet the entity's objectives
clauses.rationale: SC-28, MP-04, CP-09, and SI-12 address storage of processing data.
clauses.gaps: Covers data storage protection and backup. Gaps in storage integrity verification for processing items and specification-based storage validation.
